title.value: Global SARS-CoV-2 seroprevalence: a systematic review and meta-analysis of standardized population-based studies from Jan 2020-May 2022
title.justification: The title of the paper is clearly stated at the beginning of the document.
title.quote: Global SARS-CoV-2 seroprevalence: a systematic review and meta-analysis of standardized population-based studies from Jan 2020-May 2022

extractions.description: The paper presents a systematic review and meta-analysis of seroprevalence studies for SARS-CoV-2, aligned with the World Health Organization Unity protocol, to estimate the extent of global infection and immunity from January 2020 to May 2022.

type.justification: The research is based on empirical data collection from various studies that involve systematic reviews and are adjusted through meta-analysis, focusing on observed data rather than theoretical propositions.
type.quote: We conducted a systematic review and meta-analysis, searching MEDLINE, Embase, Web of Science, preprints, and grey literature for SARS-CoV-2 seroprevalence published between 2020-01-01 and 2022-05-20.

name.justification: The paper analyzes seroprevalence, focusing on infection spread and immunity, primary concerns of infectious disease epidemiology.
name.quote: Background Our understanding of the global scale of SARS-CoV-2 infection remains incomplete: routine surveillance data underestimates infection and cannot infer on population immunity...

name.justification: The study addresses public health concerns by providing insights into seroprevalence, which is critical for public health planning and response.
name.quote: seroprevalence studies are crucial to understand the true extent of infection overall, by demographic group, and by geographic area, as well as to estimate case under-ascertainment.

name.justification: The study employs statistical analysis and meta-analysis techniques to systematically combine and analyze data from various studies.
name.quote: We meta-analyzed seroprevalence by country and month, pooling to estimate regional and global seroprevalence over time...
